body: I'd be in favor of that and happy to help with code :+1:

For OS X, this seems to require modifying the `Info.plist`, unless there's some other mechanism to set this at runtime that I haven't discovered yet.

For Windows, this is actually pretty straightforward. I implemented it in a couple dozen lines of code, without even requiring a native dependency. [Code here](https://github.com/feross/webtorrent-app/blob/2b555e12b868b0610838e55f98a0b1d6705f49d6/main/register-protocol-handler.js#L7-L46). This uses [`winreg`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/winreg) to modify the Windows registry.Â It just calls out to the `REG` command line program with `child_process`, so it's pure JavaScript.

Winreg has a few issues for things like protocol handlers and file handlers across versions of Windows, which is why my team at Microsoft[ built this (native) alternative](https://github.com/CatalystCode/windows-registry-node), ensuring the correct ACLs for the operation.
What potential ACL issues exist with my approach? Isn't `HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes` always writable by the current user?

It is, but certain environments might not have access to regedit. Our solution just does it directly in c++, removing any dependencies.

This is mostly interesting for Visual Studio Code, Atom, and other apps that have _a lot_ of users, bringing edge cases with them.

@felixrieseberg Okay, fair enough. Thanks for explaining the potential issue. Right now, our app doesn't have any native dependencies and we're trying to keep it that way as long as possible so it's simpler to package.

For larger apps, or for a built-in Electron API, the C++ approach sounds right.

> It is, but certain environments might not have access to regedit.

This is correct, many environments inexplicably use Group Policy to block REG.exe but not editing the registry in general. Yes, this _is_ dumb.

> For OS X, this seems to require modifying the Info.plist, unless there's some other mechanism to set this at runtime that I haven't discovered yet.

Correct, on both OS X and Linux this is not possible to do :(

Actually, I'm full of it, @deepak1556 tracked down https://code.google.com/p/chromium/codesearch#chromium/src/chrome/browser/shell_integration.h&q=shell_integration&sq=package:chromium&l=45 which looks to have implementations for all platforms, I'm a :+1: on this

Nice, good find! Quick question though for you, @paulcbetts - the `navigator` API wasn't really meant for this and I'm concerned that we're just replacing an existing API with a slightly different function. I'd rather make a new API, maybe somewhere on `app`. Thoughts?
@felixrieseberg Yeah, I'd implement the same API on `app` - it's really a per-app Thing, and if in the future Chromium implemented this API, we'd conflict if we tried to patch it in
Cool. I'll take a look at this, we'll need this in Ghost, too.

> if in the future Chromium implemented this API, we'd conflict if we tried to patch it in

Chrome already implements the API :) You can see it in action here: https://instant.io (Look at the icon in the right of the Location bar)

`app.registerProtocolHandler` sounds good to me!

> Chrome already implements the API :) You can see it in action here: https://instant.io (Look at the icon in the right of the Location bar)

`navigator.registerProtocolHandler` handles protocol within the User Agent, it is similar to setting up a redirect request job with Electrons' protocol module. Can we edit the title as its misleading to the feature requested here ?
Update: OS X is done, but Windows is a bit tricky (depending on how wide our range of supported versions is).

@felixrieseberg Nice work! I see you used the code comment from WebTorrent inline :)

For Linux, feel free to re-use what we've written for WebTorrent.

.desktop file: https://github.com/feross/webtorrent-app/blob/73d5a4e1ab47c7139df836f4b7755f332d00a9c4/static/webtorrent.desktop

function: https://github.com/feross/webtorrent-app/blob/73d5a4e1ab47c7139df836f4b7755f332d00a9c4/main/register-handlers.js#L16-L31

Given that I know literally _nothing_ about how to do this on Linux, it'd probably be better if you or someone else who knows what they're doing in Linux desktop environments would tackle this in a separate PR (once #4896 is merged). You'd just have to hook in [here](https://github.com/atom/electron/pull/4896/files#diff-c23b2418b0e2c377a43e7c77b07d4e94R40).
I also know next-to-nothing about Linux. I hacked this together so we'd _something_ on Linux. Perhaps @grunjol could pitch in? He's sent a bunch of great Linux PRs to our app.

I am not expert neither but made some hacks

In the past linux DE's make whatever they want, but some years ago they follow XDG specifications.

The app can be installed for the local user or for the system, in case of the system i recommend to create a distribution package (deb, rpm, etc.), the following steps are for users apps.

As @feross said, the first thing is create the [.desktop file](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/) for the application (ie myapp.desktop). In the file you have a MIME field you can add the list of protocols the app can handle.
The .desktop file can be installed using the _xdg-desktop-menu_ command (the package xdg-utils should be installed) or you can do it manually copying it to $HOME/.local/share/applications/
You can copy an icon (ie: myapp.png) file to  $HOME/.local/share/icons/
That basically adds the app to your menus.

If you need to be default, adding the MIME line in the .desktop file doesn't automatically add the handler to be default to your app, you need to associate it adding the line 

`x-scheme-handler/myapp=myapp.desktop;` 

to either $HOME/.config/mimeapps.list or $HOME/.local/share/applications/mimeapps.list (check the existence of one or the other in that order)

You can check if its working using the command line 

`xdg-mime query default x-scheme-handler/myapp`

or test it invoking

 `xdg-open myapp://<example.protocol.data>`

For more information about this:
https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/default_applications
https://wiki.debian.org/MIME

Maybe usefull how chromium implements shell integration https://src.chromium.org/viewvc/chrome/trunk/src/chrome/browser/shell_integration_linux.cc

FWIW, I implemented the real `navigator.registerProtocolHandler` which gives websites the ability to request registration of a protocol here: https://github.com/brave/electron/commit/3a2f05bb03b1a76421dd93b344183c9a8bffbef1

Good examples of this is gmail now prompts to set as default handler for mailto: and coinbase for bitcoin: urls.

Unfortunately it requires KeyedService though which we only have in our branch with extensions support.  I'd be happy to upstream one day if Electron's stance changes on not taking in extensions support or if they get the needed support for KeyedService otherwise.

@felixrieseberg I'm looking into using this stuff and can't figure out the details of how you actually catch the event when the OS triggers your protocol.

In Mac I can catch it with 

```
app.on('open-url', ....
```

But the docs say that is mac only.

How are you actually using this ?  :)

@felixrieseberg I think I found that it's just executing the CLI - I was hoping for something more like DDE - where it can trigger an event if the process is already started.
